prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The integrated CO 6-5 line flux of NGC 6240 as measured from the Herschel SPIRE-FTS is 5910 Jy km/s. The line width FWHM is about 500 km/s, which gives a total flux density of about 12 Jy. NGC 6240 is a compact source compared to the primary beams of Herschel and ALMA (band 9), so the total flux density in CO 6-5 line is the same for both telescopes. Interferometric maps of lower-J CO lines (e.g., the CO 3-2 map from the SMA) show that NGC 6240 is a merging system with two nuclei separated by 2" with most of the molecular gas located between the two nuclei. To unambiguously resolve the two nuclei and recover any extended emission we request configuration C34-2, which will provide ~0.3" resolution with a maximum recoverable scale of 3.5".
To calculate the peak flux per resolution element of 0.3", we assume that the majority of the total flux of 12 Jy is coming from the two nuclei and is distributed evenly across 2". This gives a peak flux density ~0.3 Jy. Experience from our previous ALMA observations of Arp 220 in Band - 9 shows that high S/N is needed to unambiguously detect both nuclei and have sufficient S/N for the self-calibration process, which is a necessity in band-9 for correcting phase and amplitude errors that are hard to avoid at these frequencies except in exceptionally stable conditions. The self-calibration process worked well for Arp 220; about 90% of the total line flux (measured from Herschel) was recovered. We request similar sensitivity and resolution as obtained in our previous ALMA observations of Arp 220; the S/N was about 35 per 0.3" resolution element assuming all the line flux was uniformly distributed over the source size. To reach this S/N value, a sensitivity of about 8.5 mJy is needed for NGC 6240. We request the TDM mode to cover the large line width of 500 km/s and continuum windows, with a moderate velocity resolution of ~20 km/s.

The integrated CO 4-3 line flux of Arp 220 as measured from the Herschel SPIRE-FTS is 4550 Jy km/s. The line width FWHM is about 350 km/s, which gives a total flux density of about 13 Jy. Arp 220 is a compact source compared to the primary beams of Herschel and ALMA (Band-8), so the total flux density in the CO 6-5 line is the same for both telescopes. Arp 220 is a merging system with two nuclei separated by 1" with a large concentration of molecular gas in its nuclear region. To unambiguously resolve the two nuclei and recover any extended emission we request configuration C34-4, which will provide ~0.24" resolution with a maximum recoverable scale of ~4". This is about the same resolution as obtained in the CO J = 6-5 map (Figure 1).
To calculate the peak flux per resolution element of 0.24", we assume that the majority of the total flux of 13 Jy is coming from the two nuclei and is distributed evenly across 1.2". This gives a peak flux density of 0.52 Jy. Experience from our previous ALMA observations of Arp 220 in Band-9 shows that high S/N is needed to detect both nuclei and have sufficient S/N for the self-calibration process in Band-9. We anticipate that self-calibration may be required for Band-8 observations as well, to correct phase and amplitude errors that are hard to avoid at these frequencies except in exceptionally stable conditions. The self-calibration process worked well for Arp 220 Band-9 observations; about 90% of the total line flux (measured from Herschel) was recovered. We need spatial resolution and sensitivity similar to the CO J = 6-5 observations to be able to compare different components in the molecular gas for different CO transitions. This requires S/N = 35 per resolution element of 0.24”, giving a sensitivity of 14.8 mJy.
We request the TDM mode to cover the large line width of 500 km/s and continuum windows, with a moderate velocity resolution of ~20 km/s.

The integrated CO J=3-2 line flux in NGC 6240 is 3210 Jy km/s (Meijerink et al. 2013). The line width FWHM is about 500 km/s, which gives a total flux density of about 6.5 Jy. Interferometric maps of lower-J CO lines show that NGC 6240 is a merging system with two nuclei separated by 2" with most of the molecular gas located between the two nuclei. NGC 6240 also has significant extended emission associated with shocks seen in the CO 1-0 map from IRAM (Feruglio et al. 2013). To unambiguously resolve the two nuclei and to measure the extended emission associated with shocks, we request mapping with two different array configurations C34-5 and C34-2. The configuration C34-5 will provide 0.22" resolution with a maximum recoverable scale of 4", sufficient to resolve and map the nuclear emission. The configuration C34-2 will provide moderate spatial resolution of 0.6", which will still resolve the two nuclei, but will recover the extended emission out to 7.5”.
Calculation for configuration C34-5: To calculate the peak flux per resolution element of 0.22", we assume that the majority of the total flux of 6.5 Jy is coming from the two nuclei and is distributed evenly across 2". This gives a peak flux density of ~78mJy. We need spatial resolution and sensitivity similar to the CO J = 6-5 observations to be able to compare different components in the molecular gas for different CO transitions. This requires S/N = 35 per resolution element of 0.22”, giving a sensitivity of 2.2mJy.
We request the TDM mode to adequately cover the large line width of 500 km/s and continuum windows, with a moderate velocity resolution ~20 km/s.

The integrated CO J=3-2 line flux in NGC 6240 is 3210 Jy km/s (Meijerink et al. 2013). The line width FWHM is about 500 km/s, which gives a total flux density of about 6.5 Jy. Interferometric maps of lower-J CO lines show that NGC 6240 is a merging system with two nuclei separated by 2" with most of the molecular gas located between the two nuclei. NGC 6240 also has significant extended emission associated with shocks seen in the CO 1-0 map from IRAM (Feruglio et al. 2013). To unambiguously resolve the two nuclei and to measure the extended emission associated with shocks, we request mapping with two different array configurations C34-5 and C34-2. The configuration C34-5 will provide 0.22" resolution with a maximum recoverable scale of 4", sufficient to resolve and map the nuclear emission. The configuration C34-2 will provide moderate spatial resolution of 0.6", which will still resolve the two nuclei, but will recover the extended emission out to 7.5”.
Calculation for configuration C34-2 (for recovering extended emission): To calculate the peak flux per resolution element of 0.6", we now assume that the total flux of 6.5 Jy is spread over 7.5”. This gives a peak flux density of 41mJy. We don’t need as high a S/N in this case as our primary purpose is to recover any extended emission associated with the shocks. A S/N of 20 per resolution element will be sufficient to determine the morphology of this extended emission. A S/N = 20 gives a sensitivity of 2.05 mJy.
We request the TDM mode to adequately cover the large line width of 500 km/s and continuum windows, with a moderate velocity resolution ~20 km/s.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Herschel observations of nearby star-forming galaxies have determined that the warm component of the molecular gas traced by the high-J CO lines dominates the luminosity and hence the energy budget. Our high spatial resolution ALMA observations of the CO J=6-5 line in Arp 220 resolved the morphology of the warm molecular gas for the first time on a much finer scale than ever before, revealing interesting and unexpected features. Multiple components are seen in the resolved ALMA observations, clearly suggesting that modeling galaxy-integrated CO rotational lines is inadequate for deriving the detailed excitation and physical conditions of the gas. High spatial resolution observations of multiple CO transitions are therefore needed to compare the morphology for different CO transitions and model the various components of the molecular gas on a pixel-by-pixel basis. Therefore, we request maps of CO J=4-3 in Arp 220 and CO J=6-5/3-2 in NGC 6240; due to its similarity to Arp 220, this galaxy will allow us to determine whether the warm gas morphologies that we are seeing are peculiar to Arp 220 or may be characteristic of merging luminous infrared galaxies.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: Mapping the Distribution of Warm Molecular Gas in Arp 220 (accepted in Cycle-0)
prp:ObsProposal.prp:keyword: Luminous and Ultra-Luminous Infra-Red Galaxies (LIRG & ULIRG)
